The Internet should not be subjected to the whims of corporate balkanization, and should continue to be a level playing field for tech giants, entrepreneurs, and citizens alike. I believe that protecting net neutrality ensures that the internet remains free, fair, and accessible. I will continue to fight against Republican efforts to gut net neutrality and I not only strongly oppose FCC moves toward rolling back these important protections, I have called on the FCC Director directly to keep the current rules in place. I believe you—not the service providers or other gatekeepers—should decide what you see online. Please, share if you agree.

Every day, I strive to be a champion of our environment, both as a member of the House Natural Resources Committee and as co-chair of the House Safe Climate Caucus. I am fighting because I am very troubled by the direction this Administration is taking our nation’s environmental policy. And with the future of our environment in the hands of billionaires, corporations, and science deniers, every American who cares about our future must join the fight to make sure our government does what is right. We simply cannot get this wrong. There is no do over once our public lands are sold off and our environment is trashed.

A new study from the Union of Concerned Scientists shows that areas of the 47th District will be flooded more frequently and further inland by rising sea waters much sooner than previously predicted. By 2100, coastal areas of the Los Angeles and Orange counties’ coast lines will be inundated more than 26 times a year—some areas reaching that frequency as early as 2040. Sea level rise is not going to wait while we decide what to do. We must begin planning and taking action now.  http://www.ucsusa.org/sites/default/files/attach/2017/07/when-rising-seas-hit-home-california-fact-sheet.pdf

Over the weekend, Secretary of Health and Human Services Tom Price was confronted during an ABC interview with the facts about how massively unpopular the GOP repeal and replace bills are. Sec. Price, the man charged with overseeing the health programs of the federal government, said the GOP plan will take us back to the pre-ACA era when insurance companies literally decided who had coverage and who didn't. Let’s not forget that prior to the ACA:  • There were annual and lifetime limits on care. • Being a woman was a pre-existing condition. • Americans with pre-existing conditions and disabilities were charged more or denied coverage. • Families were forced to pay staggering out-of-pocket costs for fewer protections.

The GOP’s current effort to repeal and replace Obamacare has collapsed. I join with other Democrats in extending a hand of bipartisanship if the GOP will  move past ACA repeal, abandon cuts to Medicaid, and set aside huge tax breaks for the wealthy. My colleagues and I have put forward innumerable pieces of thoughtful and thought out legislation to strengthen Obamacare, Medicaid, and Medicare. The solutions are there and we are willing to bring them to the table again. It is time to come together to work on what is in the best interest of the American people.

I was the first Member of Congress to permanently fly the Pride Flag outside my office on Capitol Hill. I fly the flag there in support of every LGBTQ individual—those in my district, those in our nation, and those across the world. It is a symbol of both how far we have come on equality for all Americans and how far we still have to go. It is a symbol of love, of peace, and diversity. Earlier this year when it was attacked by a visitor and desecrated, I was overwhelmed by the outpouring of support on social media.   Now I am being sued by an individual who is “offended” by my Pride Flag and demands that it be removed (and, marriage equality reversed). I will fight this hateful attempt to silence equality and justice. We have come too far to allow the voices of bigotry and hate to win.

I want to thank everyone for their tremendous support regarding my vow to fight the recently filed lawsuit seeking to remove the Pride Flag from outside my office. I will continue to fly the Pride Flag outside my office as a symbol of tolerance, love, and inclusivity to every visitor to Capitol Hill. I find it simply unbelievable that such intolerance, weakly cloaked in the guise of the law, continues to rear its ugly head. This lawsuit is patently frivolous, at times legally incoherent, and seeks only to promote bigotry and hate over the message of love and diversity that the Pride Flag stands for. I am confident that the judge will dismiss the case out of hand. I will fight this and any future effort to move us backward as a nation and as a people.

In the last six months, the GOP has put forward four versions of a bill to repeal and/or replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA). Unlike the ACA, not a single one of these bills would increase the number of Americans covered. In fact, according to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office the various bills would threaten the health insurance of, respectively, 23 million, 22 million, 32 million, or 22 million Americans who currently have coverage. Compare this to the 11.4 million Americans who gained coverage under the ACA and another 9 million that gained coverage under the ACA Medicaid expansion. Doesn’t it make sense to strengthen the plan that actually increased the number of people covered?

The conservative lobbying group ALEC -- the most influential power behind conservative legislation marching through state legislatures -- is pushing for a repeal of the 17th Amendment to the Constitution. This would end more than 100 years of American voters electing U.S. senators at the ballot box and allow the corrupt practice of gerrymandered state legislatures choosing their state’s senators in backroom deals, just as it was done before 1913. This makes them beholden to political parties and other politicians, not voters. This is yet another effort to move us backwards as a nation. I also believe that the American people will not sit by and quietly allow this to happen.

The GOP Members of the Senate have moved one step closer in their irrational Captain Ahab-like quest to kill the Affordable Care Act. This ‘motion to proceed’ vote—which passed 51-50—simply allows debate and votes on one or more of the GOP repeal and replace bills, though it remains unclear what bill or bills the GOP will bring to the Senate floor. One thing is clear, though--today’s vote moved at least 15 million Americans, and as many as 32 million, one step closer to losing health insurance. The voice of the American people has stopped these kinds of destructive actions before and it can stop it again.

President Trump said today that the he will not allow transgender Americans to serve in the US military “in any capacity.” He did so using the same old hateful script: B̶l̶a̶c̶k̶s̶ W̶o̶m̶e̶n̶ G̶a̶y̶s̶ Transgender individuals would cause “disruption in the military.” Which, of course, never proves to be true. This from the man who told the LGBT community, ‘I will fight for you,’ and that he would do ‘everything in his power to protect LGBTQ citizens.’ Today’s action makes clear, once and for all, that the President is not an ally, nor even neutral on LGBT equality. He is an opponent, plain and simple. We need to recognize this fact.

On July 26, 1948, 69 years ago today, President Harry Truman officially desegregated the US Military. So it is ironically distasteful that the President chose this anniversary to issue his hateful decision barring the more than 16,000 transgender military service members from continuing to serve our nation “in any capacity.” I was proud to join with my House colleagues today in calling out this wholly un-American action. Any American that wishes to honorably serve their country should be allowed.

There have been many times over the years that I have not agreed with Sen. John McCain. However, last night’s vote to keep a truly dreadful GOP repeal and replace bill from passing, showed once again that he clearly understands that there are times to put country above party. It was a courageous move and one I hope we as a legislative body can build on. We must come together to repair and strengthen the Affordable Care Act. There is no reason that we can’t use this moment as an opportunity to move forward and do what is right for the American people.

It was an amazing experience to meet last week with Miranda Speirs, a seventh-grader from Long Beach who was in Washington as part of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF) 2017 Children’s Congress. Miranda, who lives with type 1 diabetes, was one of 160+ delegates selected by the JDRF to visit their own Congressional representatives in Washington, D.C. and discuss what it is like to live with juvenile diabetes and what is needed to advance medical research into solutions and treatments for young boys and girls like Miranda.  I have met with many people during my time in Congress, on a wide range of topics, and Miranda was one of the most engaging, charming, and convincing advocates I have met. She shared with me how diabetes impacts her, taught me about the scientific advances being made regarding her disease, showed me how she checks her blood glucose level, and challenged me to keep supporting scientific and medical research on juvenile diabetes. I also felt privileged when she asked to share with me her scrapbook of her life, her friends, and her accomplishments. A truly remarkable young woman I was proud to spend some time with.

Los Angeles will host its third Olympics, this time in 2028. Long Beach played a big part in the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, including events like volleyball at the Long Beach Arena, fencing at the LB Convention Center, sailing at Shoreline Marina and just off the coast, and archery in El Dorado Park. Just as in 1984, Long Beach is poised to once again play an important role in the 2028 Olympics with a half-dozen venues hosting events like handball, sailing, water polo, triathlon, open water swimming, and sport climbing. Another moment for Long Beach to shine.

I hope everyone can take a few minutes to read my editorial in the Press-Telegram about the President’s recent call to ban an estimated 15,000 transgender service members from continuing to serve our nation. I think his proposed ban makes clear which side of LGBT equality the President is on.

I wanted to remind everyone of my posted social media policy for this page:  This is an official page for policy discussion only.  Posts to this Facebook page which contain profanity, personal attacks, name-calling, and/or other inappropriate off-topic comments will be removed. Abusive, excessively disruptive, and/or harassing posts will also be removed.  Repeated violation of these terms will result in violators being blocked.  Also, under U.S. House of Representatives ethics laws, no comments on campaign/election issues are permitted and will be removed.  Communications will be monitored and appropriate action will be taken in order to ensure that these policies are consistently adhered to.

Contrary to the beliefs of the Trump Administration, government scientists agree: the Earth is rapidly warming and mankind is the main reason. A more than 500-page draft report--written by scientists from 13 government agencies including the EPA and NOAA--concludes that temperatures across the nation have risen dramatically in the past 150 years, that the last several decades have been the warmest in 1,500 years, and that most of the rise is extremely likely to be man-made in origin. A head-in-the-sand approach to climate change is not viable. We simply cannot wait to take action.

I just returned from two days in Mexico City, Mexico where I met with U.S. and Mexican government officials, human rights activists, journalists, and the families of the 43 students that were forcibly disappeared in Iguala, Guerrero, in September 2014.  It was both a humbling and heartening experience for me. The pain and anguish these families have endured is simply unimaginable. I was humbled by the strength they have shown throughout this tragedy and heartened by their perseverance to learn what happened to their children and their determination to never let them be forgotten.   There is one question these families want, need, and deserve to have answered. Where are their children? It is a question that after nearly three years the Mexican government still needs to answer. It is critical that everything be done to ensure that we discover what happened to the 43 students and hold the perpetrators accountable.

What occurred in Charlottesville was horrible. My heart goes out to those who were injured and to the families and loved ones of those who died. But it was not just horrible for the broken lives the violence left behind, but also because it peeled back a layer of our society to view something many had not seen before. A dark layer fueled by all the horrible impulses that a civilized society rightly banishes to the dark corners. Hate. Bigotry. Prejudice. Misogyny. These were the members of the torch-carrying mob. They believe in supremacy and white power and blood and soil. Their views run counter to everything it means to be an American. Their hate and bigotry are at odds with everything that America stands for. In the face of what happened in Charlottesville, and the alarming fact that the number of hate groups has more than doubled in the past two decades, this racism and hatred must not stand unchecked. It must be called out and it must be confronted. We cannot stand silent. As John Stuart Mill said, "Bad men need nothing more to compass their ends, than that good men should look on and do nothing."

The President's comments today are simply disgusting. As a proud Jewish American, I can say with almost certainty that there are no 'fine people' at a torch lit Nazi rally. Ever. What you do find at Nazi rallies is violence. You find hatred. You find bigotry. These are the ideas that white supremacists, Nazi's, and the KKK bring to the public square. We defeated these hateful un-American ideas in 1865, in 1945, and in 1965. I have no doubt we will defeat them now. Our country has come together to overcome this vile hatred before, and will do so again. The arc of the universe must continue to bend toward justice.

There is nothing to celebrate about the Confederacy. It was created with the supreme goal of defending and forever enshrining the enslavement of an entire race of human beings. Its leaders were traitors to the United States. It cost the lives of more than 350,000 Union soldiers, not to mention the almost 300,000 Confederate soldiers who were led to their death in the name of a horrible cause. And, it directly led to the death of one of the greatest presidents in American history. Nothing about the Confederacy is noble or deserving of honor except the lives that were lost. What these Confederate statues represent is the cause of the Confederacy, and that cause was slavery, bigotry, and hatred. They are the antithesis of what it means to be an American. These statues deserve no place in history other than as relics to remind us of the horrible cause they represent.
Multiple news outlets are reporting that President Trump's Chief Strategist Steve Bannon is out at the White House.

I joined yesterday with 17 of my Jewish American colleagues in the House in calling out President Trump for his repeated comments equating anti-Semitic neo-Nazi’s to protesters opposing them. The letter asks the President to stand up to hate and “consistently and unequivocally fight against racists and anti-Semites. Anything less is beneath the dignity of your office and the ideals of our great nation.” You can read the whole letter on my website by clicking below.     https://lowenthal.house.gov/UploadedFiles/JewishMembersLettertoTrump_081717.pdf

Today’s decision to stop investigating the health impacts of mountaintop mining crystallizes this Administration’s policy of putting mining companies ahead of public health. This Administration is simply not interested in the health and welfare of those people who live closest to mountaintop mines, nor in any scientific inquiry that may undermine its pro-mining stance. As the ranking member of the Energy and Mineral Resources subcommittee, I will continue to advocate for science-based health and safety protections for the people who live closest to these mines. I find it unconscionable that this Administration can so cavalierly put the interests of mining corporations and their wealthy CEO’s over the health of the people of Appalachia.

Interior Secretary Zinke has recommended to President Trump that some of the National Monuments under review by the Interior Department should be reduced in size. He didn’t mention which of these national treasures should be downsized, nor did he say if any of the affected land would be open to commercial development. However, this really comes as no surprise to anyone who has followed this ‘review’ process. It seems more a fait accompli directed at a few monuments than a serious review. It serves simply as justification for this pro-corporate and pro-mining Administration to further tear down the protections of our public lands. These lands belong to every American and to every future American, not big companies concerned with quarterly profits. As a member of the House Natural Resource Committee and the ranking Member on the Energy and Mineral Resources subcommittee, I will resist any effort to turn our public lands over to corporations.

The Trump administration continues to disregard the rights of individuals while exulting those that represent the darkest corners of the American psyche. The signing of the transgender ban by the President is only reinforcement to the idea that he not only disregards the rights of LGBT Americans, but is determined to marginalize the 15,000 brave American transgender service members who currently serve in our military. And his pardon of former-Sheriff Joe Arpaio, a man found guilty of disregarding a court order to stop racial profiling, only highlights this administration's disdain for the Constitutional rights of Americans. No one should be above the law, but the President has decided that loyalty to him--Arpaio is one of his staunchest defenders--overrides the rule of law. Both decisions--the transgender ban and the pardon of Arpaio--are embarrassing coming from the leader of a country founded on the principle that we are all created equal.

Despite Hurricane Harvey being downgraded, the people of Texas are still not out of danger. The damage caused by the unprecedented flooding now going on will take months if not years to fully repair. My thoughts and prayers go out to all of the people impacted by this storm. I especially want to express my gratitude for the amazing first responders and those many citizens who threw themselves in harms way to protect and save their fellow Texans. The federal government has to do whatever it can to make sure Texans have the emergency shelter and supplies they need right now, and the resources to begin rebuilding once the waters start to recede.

On Sunday, I participated along with Rabbi Jonathan Klein, Executive Director of CLUE (Clergy and Laity United for Economic Justice), on an Immigration Rights Forum at Temple Israel in Long Beach. Rabbi Klein provided an overview of Jewish immigration history and experience, while I provided an update on the current state of our broken immigration system. Just last Friday, ABC news reported that, according to multiple sources, President Trump is leaning toward ending DACA.  As a member of the Jewish faith, I cannot ignore the shared experience of those living in exile and the difficulties of migrating to a new land. “Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free.” These words from Emma Lazarus’ poem, New Colossus, inscribed at the base of the Statue of Liberty, have never been so important.

While reports indicate that flood waters have crested in the Houston area, the devastation from Harvey is far from over. Texas still faces months if not years of recovery and Louisiana is still facing more flooding. If you want to know how you can help, the FEMA website has details on how to volunteer or donate responsibly.

The people of Cambodia have been dealt a serious blow with the arrest of Cambodian opposition party leader Kem Sokha in Phnom Penh by the Cambodian government. This anti-democratic move is yet another in a long line of attacks on political freedom by the authoritarian regime of Prime Minister Hun Sen aimed at depriving the Cambodian people of their freedom of political expression. It also confirms the greatest fears of the international community that Hun Sen has no intention of allowing free and fair elections next year. The people of Cambodia have endured over three decades of rule under Hun Sen, and they deserve their constitutionally guaranteed rights to determine the fate of their government. Their voice is being silenced. The United States cannot sit idly by while these abrogations of the Cambodian constitution continue. I will continue to advocate for our nation--through the State Department, through the White House, and through the United Nations--to bring to bear all the political pressure we can to reverse these abuses and assure the right of political determination not be stripped from the Cambodian people.

As we celebrate Labor Day, let's remember the major advancements that the American labor movement have brought to the lives of American workers. Prior to the first national Labor Day celebrations in 1894, the average American work week was 61 hours. The five day work week was a direct result of demands made by labor unions that were eventually codified in the federal Fair Labor Standards Act. The labor movement also led to the ban on child labor, one of the greatest expansions of employer-based health coverage in US history, and more recently the adoption of family and medical leave for workers. Yet, this Labor Day, worker's rights are under attack like never before. American workers, whether in a union or not, deserve fairness, safety, and the freedom to demand their workplace rights under the law. American workers built this country, just as they will build the future.

The President’s decision today to end DACA is cruel, heartless, and un-American. It will exile 800,000 young adults and children from the only country that many of them have ever known, to countries they don’t know. Their life is here and for the most part always has been. These Dreamers are Americans in all but their birth certificates. Congress must now provide the leadership that is so lacking from this administration. It is time for Congress to pass legislation to protect these Dreamers permanently, once and for all.

More than 80 times a year, an endangered blue, humpback or fin whale is struck and killed by a cargo vessel along the California coast. Today, I introduced my Blue Whales, Blue Skies legislation that would encourage vessels to slow down in coastal shipping lanes such as the Santa Barbara Channel. Studies have shown that when vessels slow down, whale strikes decline. Read more about my legislation on my website.

I met an amazing young woman today during a DACA event on the Hill. Her name is Fernanda Herrera Vera, and she is a Dreamer and DACA recipient. She was brought to the U.S. nearly 20 years ago when she was just over 2 years old. She just graduated from Samford University in Alabama with a degree in International Relations and Pre-Law. Fernanda reminds me of so many Dreamers I have met in the 47th District. Strong, dedicated, and resilient. I am a supporter of the DREAM Act and the American Hope Act because of Dreamers like Fernanda. Both of these bills would provide permanent legal status and a pathway to citizenship for close to 800,000 people just like her.

What does democracy sound like when it is silenced? I am deeply disappointed by the GOP leadership's decision to block debate on crucial environmental and climate protection measures. Today, the House debated a major funding bill covering most government agencies outside of defense. I, like nearly all Members, submitted a handful of amendments to the bill to address issues that I believe are important to my constituents. GOP leadership—operating outside of regular order—refused to allow all but one of my amendments to even be debated on the Floor. Most Democratic Members experienced the same thing.   The GOP leadership refused to let the House debate my bipartisan amendment to prevent dangerous offshore drilling along the Pacific Coast. They blocked debate over measures to protect our communities from methane pollution and to ensure sound stewardship of our mineral resources. They blocked an effort to ensure that crucial government data on climate change is not suppressed by the Trump administration. And--even in the wake of Hurricane Harvey--the GOP said “no” to open debate of the Green Climate Fund, blocking consideration of efforts to protect funding that helps vulnerable communities cope with climate change.  Speaker Ryan and the GOP leadership promised a return to “regular order,” but blocking these and other amendments silences representatives of the American people. These are not the actions of a secure party, who believe they can win arguments on the force of their ideals. We deserve better.

Today, I was proud to vote for bipartisan legislation providing $15.25 billion in Hurricane Harvey relief, and avoiding a government shutdown and default. A real win for all of us.   Of the $15.25 billion, more than $7 billion of the funds will go to the Disaster Relief Fund within FEMA to continue the federal response to the hurricane and subsequent flooding. Another $450 million will go toward the Small Business Administration’s Disaster Loan Program to provide low-interest emergency loans to help small businesses and homeowners in the disaster area. And, $7.4 billion will go toward federal Community Development Block Grants for disaster relief, recovery, and restoration of infrastructure and housing in impacted areas.  The legislation also allows flexibility for some of the funds to be spent on any needed recovery efforts for Hurricane Irma and it extends the National Flood Insurance Program through December.  The bill also contained critical language raising the debt limit through December which will avoid a government shutdown and a U.S. credit default.  This was a good example of Congress working together to do the right thing for the American people. A real win for all of us.
Today we remember those lost, honor those who responded, and cherish those who survived on 9/11.

Equifax, one of the three main consumer credit reporting agencies, has revealed that hackers gained access to company data possibly compromising personal and sensitive information for 143 million American consumers--including driver’s license and Social Security numbers. If you you are worried about identity theft due to this massive hack, you aren’t alone, and there are steps you can take to protect your personal information.

As a member of the Natural Resources Committee’s Subcommittee on Federal Lands, today I joined in our subcommittee discussion of the SHARE Act, introduced by the GOP majority. While hiding under the guise of enhancing opportunities for recreational hunting and fishing on public lands, the SHARE Act is actually an assault on both conservation and gun safety laws.  First, it would undermine some of our nation’s bedrock conservation laws, such as the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) and the Endangered Species Act, and it fails to authorize important programs like the Land and Water Conservation Fund.   Perhaps the most troubling aspect of this bill, however, is the extent to which it weakens some of our nation’s most essential common sense gun safety laws. This bill literally puts lives at risk and makes it more difficult to prosecute criminals over firearms abuses.  The bill authors want to make silencers—whose sole purpose is to make gunfire harder to detect—easier to obtain.  It would also allow some now-illegal armor piercing ammunition—that is fully capable of piercing body armor like that worn by law enforcement—to be sold, as long as ammunition manufacturers label it for “sporting” purposes.   And most shocking, the bill seeks to allow gun owners in states with fewer gun safety laws to freely travel with their weapons to states with more restrictive gun safety laws.   I believe strongly in ensuring that sportsmen and sportswomen are able to enjoy all the recreational opportunities our public lands have to offer, but this legislation attacks the very conservation laws that protect those federal lands, seriously relaxes commonsense gun safety precautions, and puts lives at risk from gun violence.

Edie Windsor, the LGBT-rights activist at the center of one of the most important marriage equality rulings in U.S. history passed away Tuesday. Her case, which the U.S. Supreme Court ruled on in 2013, granted federal recognition to same-sex married couples for the first time. The ruling was a critical step toward full equality which the Supreme Court ruled on in 2015. “Married is a magic word,” she once said. “And it is magic throughout the world. It has to do with our dignity as human beings, to be who we are openly.” Edie was a true hero of the fight for equality and human rights. All Americans are in her debt.

Radio Free Asia provides independent news in many countries throughout Asia. Yesterday, under continued threats and provocations from the regime of Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, the organization was forced to shutter its operations inside Cambodia. Here is the statement I issued yesterday:  “The Hun Sen regime is making it perfectly clear that it has no intention of allowing a free press to exist in Cambodia, and the government appears ready to use any contrivance it can—intimidation, threats, coercion, and even outright violence—to prevent the people of Cambodia from having independent, reliable, and trustworthy news that is not filtered through the Hun Sen lens.   “RFA in Cambodia has faced a growing escalation of rhetoric from the Hun Sen regime, and now, for the safety of its staff, RFA has been forced to cease operations in Cambodia. It joins the Cambodia Daily newspaper, numerous non-governmental agencies, as well as FM broadcast stations that have been forced to close by the government.  “The democratic principles that the Cambodia people are guaranteed under their constitution are being destroyed—one at a time—by the Hun Sen government and I am appalled.  “The right of political expression, the right of a free media, and the right to dissent, are all being quashed by Hun Sen in an effort to subvert free and fair national elections in Cambodia scheduled for next year.  “This is a crisis situation and I call on the United States ambassador to Cambodia as well as the Secretary of State to express my concern and urge them to take any and all action to stop this out of control situation and assist the Cambodian people.”  https://lowenthal.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398885

Recent actions taken by Kris Kobach and the President’s "election integrity" commission further show that they are not acting in good faith, and are instead pushing forward an agenda – an agenda to suppress American’s voting rights. Last week Kris Kobach, the commission’s Vice Chairman, wrote a piece for the extremely partisan Brietbart, where he introduced the unsubstantiated claim that 5,513 votes cast in New Hampshire in 2016 were fraudulent. Of course, it turned out that the votes were most likely students and others who legally live and vote in New Hampshire without obtaining a NH driver’s license.  Then this week, at the second meeting of the commission in New Hampshire, where Kris Kobach defended his assertions, another member of the commission, Hans von Spakovsky, admitted to writing an email to the Administration advocating against including any Democrats or mainstream Republicans. This commission is a farce built toward the sole purpose of dismantling the rights of Americans to vote.

This is the biggest attack on our most treasured natural places our country has ever seen. Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke’s reported recommendation to shrink and remove safeguards from 10 National Monuments would hand over millions of acres of iconic public lands to mining,  drilling, and logging interests, and does nothing to improve public access for hunting, fishing, hiking, or the myriad of other uses enjoyed by all Americans. The Trump Administration should re-think this deeply unpopular agenda and listen to the voices of the millions of Americans who have rallied in support of our public lands.

I am disappointed that an opportunity to stabilize and strengthen the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has been missed—all in the name of leveraging votes for the horrible Cassidy-Graham repeal and replace bill. House Speaker Ryan reportedly told Senate GOP leadership he opposed the bipartisan Murray-Alexander stabilization bill being drafted in the Senate. The White House has also expressed a similar sentiment. While I believe we should be working to fix the ACA, Speaker Ryan and the White House believe the exact opposite: undermine the ACA and repeal it through Cassidy-Graham. This is not how to help the American people.

We all remember how awful the proposed GOP repeal and replace bills were. Anywhere from 20-24 million people losing healthcare coverage. Now the Senate’s Cassidy-Graham repeal and replace bill is heading toward a vote next week, and by all appearances, it may be the worst yet. Major Medicaid cuts to states like California that did the right thing and expanded Medicaid. Under the bill state’s could allow insurers to charge those with pre-existing conditions much more—essentially pricing them out of coverage. It also turns health care funding into block grants to states that would be insufficient and vanish entirely in 10 years. Worst of all, the Senate GOP is not allowing enough time for the Congressional Budget Office to analyze the bill and determine its impacts. There is no doubt however, that millions will still lose coverage under this horrible plan. It must not pass.

Mexico has suffered its second major earthquake in two weeks. I am deeply saddened by the loss of life and the images and video of damage throughout Mexico. I reached out today to the Mexican Ambassador to the U.S. to offer my sympathy, my condolences, and my support.   Also, anyone who has friends or family in the Mexico City region may find the information in this Press-Telegram article helpful.

The Senate GOP is trying to rush through the Cassidy-Graham plan as their last ditch effort to repeal important provisions in the ACA before the Sep. 30th budget reconciliation deadline. This tight deadline means that it will not go through the open committee process and will not see a full report from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. We have had access to the language of the plan for less than a week and it will take at least a few weeks to get an accurate idea of exactly how damaging this will be. This is an irresponsible way to push forward healthcare legislation which will have detrimental effects for our nation. According to an initial estimate by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, California could lose $27.8-billion alone over the next decade alone. We must ensure that this terrible bill doesn’t pass.

The Cassidy-Graham plan essentially ends Medicaid, puts the burden on States, then, cuts their funding to address healthcare for families and individuals in poverty. It is built around underfunded block grants to States that will lead to higher costs passed on to you, the consumer. States would also be able to allow insurance providers to charge individuals with preexisting conditions more, pricing them out of being able to afford health insurance. All of this would result in tens of millions of Americans losing their health insurance. Our countries emergencies rooms should be the last recourse, but under the latest Senate GOP plan, emergencies rooms will become the primary healthcare option of last resort for tens of millions of Americans. We must ensure that this terrible bill doesn’t pass.

Helen Huynh is a constituent of the 47th District fighting for her life against leukemia. A promising treatment would be a stem cell transplant, which requires finding a person who is a compatible match. Helen’s sister, Thuy, is a 100 percent match, but she lives in Vietnam. She has been denied a visa to come to the US for the stem cell procedure three times. This is outrageous and I am doing everything I can to make sure this wrong is corrected--and it will be corrected. I am working with Helen’s family, the State Department, and the Department of Homeland Security, to make sure that we succeed in bringing Thuy to Helen as soon as possible.

It has been a tragic couple of months for natural disasters in North America. As our nation continues to recover from major hurricanes that devastated the Gulf coast region, the Southeast, Puerto Rico, and the US Virgin Islands, as well as devastating wildfires in the West, our neighbors in the Caribbean are facing a third major hurricane and Mexico continues to recover from severe back-to-back earthquakes.  Southern California is no stranger to natural disasters and we especially know what it is like to live through and recover from devastating earthquakes and fires. We also know how important the help of others outside our community has been when disasters have struck our region in the past.  I, like so many of you, have been saddened by the stories of recent destruction in our own nation, in the Caribbean, and in Mexico, and have asked myself, "What can I do?"  If you wish to help by donating to relief efforts for any of the recent natural disasters, it is important that you do your own research before you give.  This article is one good place to start.

I was proud to speak yesterday on the House Floor about my constituent Helen Huynh, who is fighting leukemia and needs a stem cell transplant. I am working with numerous government agencies to quickly get her sister in Vietnam—a 100 percent match for the procedure--to the US.

Three years ago yesterday, 43 students from Ayotzinapa, Mexico disappeared. I recently traveled to Mexico where I spoke with many of the parents and family members of the disappeared students. I was humbled by the strength they have shown throughout their three-year struggle to get the answers to two simple questions: What happened the night that their children were taken, and where are their children now?  On this anniversary I am repeating my past calls for the Mexican government to prioritize the search for the students, bring to justice those responsible for their disappearance, and investigate any obstruction of justice. If the Mexican government cannot do this, I urge them to allow the independent panel of experts to expand on their initial investigation.  The students, their parents, and the Mexican people deserve answers.

Yesterday, I joined with nearly 150 of my colleagues in calling on President Trump to fully utilize all the resources of the U.S. military to address the growing humanitarian crisis in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Watch my video below to understand why I think this is so critical following the devastation caused by Hurricanes Marie and Irma.

Many of you have heard me speak recently about the case of Helen Huynh, a resident of my district who is fighting an aggressive form of leukemia and needs a stem cell transplant from her sister--a 100 percent compatible match to Helen. However, her sister lives in Vietnam and has been denied a U.S. temporary visa to visit the U.S. for the treatment three times.   I'm proud to announce that today, the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Service granted Helen's sister humanitarian parole.This is amazing news and means that Helen's sister will soon be heading to the U.S. to help Helen get the treatment she needs. A lot of people worked together to make this happen. You can read my statement on the announcement here:
I was moved to see my colleague Rep. Steve Scalise on the floor today. He has been courageous, and I wish him and his family well through his continued recovery.

In my message to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month, I talk about the contributions the Latino community has made to our nation and why, given the current political climate in our nation, it is more important than ever for us to focus on what our growing Latino community means for this nation.

It’s really a sad day for America when a Cabinet Member has so utterly disregarded the ethics and responsibility of his position that he must resign. Price traveled as if he was the CEO of a huge corporation and not a representative of the people. I am glad that the President has accepted his resignation. This is just another example of what appears to be serious ethical failings throughout the Administration.
Devastated by the despicable and senseless shooting in Las Vegas last night. My heart goes out to all those injured and the loved ones of those killed.

This is not the time for another moment of silence. This is time to act. Because if not now, then when? Columbine, Virginia Tech, Tucson, Aurora, Newtown, Santa Barbara, Charleston, San Bernardino, Orlando, Dallas, now Las Vegas. How many innocent Americans must be murdered before Congress stands up to groups like the NRA and acts?  The people must demand action--of Congress and every elected official in the nation.  There are few if any reasons for a civilian to have an automatic weapon. We must also end the farce of how easy semi-automatic weapons can be converted, either through wink-and-nod cheats like bumping or sliding, or, through illegal conversions. The parts to do this are readily available on the Internet and with instructions sold--for nearly every semi-automatic weapon available--on Amazon for a few dollars.  This is madness. We must act.

Federal health care funding for children nationwide is in serious jeopardy. The Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP)—a federal program which offers low-cost health coverage for children in families that make too much to qualify for Medicaid but cannot afford private insurance—covers more than 9 million children nationwide. The GOP leadership in Congress failed to reauthorize the CHIP funding, which expired Saturday. California’s portion of the CHIP will run out before the end of the year, leaving more than 2 million California children without health coverage.

Today, I was proud to stand and speak on the steps of the Supreme Court as inside the Court heard oral arguments on what is without a doubt the most important case that the Justices will hear this year. The future and health of our democracy is literally at stake. The case, Gill v Whitford, could finally end hyperpartisan gerrymandering and restore democracy and real accountability into our election processes throughout the country. I was proud to lead the legislative effort that eventually led to California’s Independent Citizen Redistricting Commission, and I have been just as proud to lead a bipartisan amicus brief on this Supreme Court case so that we can finally end the backroom process of politicians picking their voters, instead of the people picking their representatives. We must end gerrymandering to restore faith, equity, and fairness in our elections.

Helen Huynh’s sister, Thuy, arrived at LAX this morning. I am glad that she will finally be able to be a stem cell donor and that the treatment to help Helen can begin. Pictured below is Helen’s husband and two of her three daughters welcoming Thuy (in middle back). I hope everyone will join me in keeping Helen, Thuy, and the Huynh family in our thoughts.

I wanted to thank former California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, who I was proud to join with yesterday on the steps of the US Supreme Court to rally against gerrymandering. I served in the California Legislature during his tenure as Governor and he was a fierce advocate for an independent redistricting commission in California. Through his hard work--along with that of many others like California Common Cause--California voters approved the creation of the California Citizens Redistricting Commission in 2008. We may be from different parties, but our united stand proves that the fight against partisan gerrymandering can and should be a truly bipartisan issue. I’m proud to stand with him again in the fight to take the ballot box out of the hands of the political parties and give it back to the voters, as we did in California. You can see my full remarks at the Supreme Court rally yesterday on CSPAN here: https://www.c-span.org/video/?c4684588/congressman-lowenthal-gerrymandering

I was also pleased to be able to sit down today with the daughter of Cambodian opposition leader Kem Sokha, who was arrested on blatantly trumped up charges by the Cambodian government last month. Mona Kem remains strong in the face of her government’s oppression, and I was grateful for the insight she offered me into the current political situation in Cambodia.

US Attorney General Jeff Sessions has once again reinterpreted the landmark 1964 Civil Rights Act to fit his seemingly narrow view of the world. Sessions announced today that the Department of Justice will now take the legal position that federal law does not protect transgender Americans from discrimination at work. This offensive move all but legalizes discrimination against transgender Americans nationwide. The Trump/Sessions DOJ is making it clear that discrimination is condoned at the highest levels of this Administration.

While the Trump Administration and the Congressional GOP have been unable to pass sweeping legislation repealing the Affordable Healthcare Act, out of the spotlight both have been relentlessly attacking our nation’s environmental protections. Despite my efforts and those of many of my colleagues—including some Republicans—the Administration and GOP leadership have managed to tear up nearly 50 environmental protections covering everything from car emission standards and safer mining on federal lands, to action on climate change. Removing these protections will have devastating impacts on our environment and the health and well-being of every American.

Just over two weeks after Hurricane Maria tore through the island, the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Governor of Puerto Rico report that about 45 percent of Puerto Ricans still have no access to potable drinking water and a little over 90 percent of the population still lack electricity. While the good news is that all of Puerto Rico’s airports and 75 percent of all sea ports are now open, only 30 miles of the island’s more than 1,000-mile highway/expressway network has been cleared and open. Supplies and relief materials arriving via air and water continue to back up at ports and airports due to the lack of open and safe roads. Puerto Rico remains a catastrophic humanitarian disaster that we must remain focused on.  I have communicated my concerns about our relief efforts in a letter to the President; I have called for a Congressional oversight hearing on the response effort; and, I have voted to increase funds for hurricane relief. We cannot allow Puerto Rico to be forgotten. These are our fellow American citizens fighting for their lives. We cannot fail them.

While Northern California is dealing with major wildfires that have killed 11 people, injured at least 100, and destroyed about 1,500 structures, the Canyon 2 wildfire burning in our own Anaheim Hills has swelled to more than 6,000 acres. According to the Orange County Fire Authority, more than 1,000 firefighters are battling the fire which began on Monday morning. Gov. Brown has declared a state of emergency for Orange County, as well as four counties in the Napa region.   My heart goes out to all those affected by the fires in both Northern and Southern California. I also pray that the thousands of firefighters on the front lines remain safe. President Trump’s EPA head Scott Pruitt said his agency is taking formal steps to repeal the carbon pollution-cutting Clean Power Plan (CPP) that, when unveiled in 2015, became the signature environmental policy of President Obama. The CPP requires states to reduce carbon pollution by cleaning up electrical power generation plants, often by moving to cleaner fuel sources. Rescinding the CPP will only slow the transition to cleaner, healthier forms of energy. The CPP was projected to cut power generation sector emissions by at least 32 percent from 2005 levels. With power generation contributing a third of U.S. carbon emissions, this would have been a significant cut, and was a major component of the U.S. commitment to the Paris Accord—which President Trump also pulled out of earlier this year. Ignoring the reality of carbon pollution to bestow favors on billionaire, dirty-energy, special interests harms the health and well being of our families and communities.

Today, the House GOP launched their latest assault on the Antiquities Act, legislation which has protected some of our most treasured public lands for more than a century. The GOP’s National Monument Creation and Protection Act is the latest iteration of a familiar GOP agenda: removing protections from vast areas of public land to benefit corporate special interests like mining, logging, and petroleum developers. This proposed legislation would drastically narrow the scope of the Antiquities Act and cap the size of new national monuments, opening the door for corporate exploitation of potentially millions of acres of land currently owned by the public and protected by law. I am proud to join with my Democratic colleagues on the Natural Resources Committee to fight against this senseless effort to attack some of our nation’s most valuable treasures.

We continue to receive disturbing reports from Puerto Rico regarding food shortages, lack of electricity or clean water, shattered infrastructure, and a rising death toll. Our fellow U.S. citizens are living through a humanitarian emergency on U.S. soil. Many federal first responders are working bravely and under extremely difficult conditions, but the pace of the response since the disaster raises serious questions about the degree to which President Trump’s Administration has prioritized relief efforts. The president’s tone and attitude with regard to the crisis, as reflected in his repeated public statements, has failed to provide the moral or technical leadership that Americans deserve in a time of crisis. Ultimately, though, the immense scale of the disaster and the unique logistical challenges faced by the island mean that Congress must respond to provide long term aid for rebuilding. This is our duty as Americans. We must also aggressively move to learn the lessons of Hurricane Maria. It will not be the last disaster our country will face.

While the exact impacts remain to be seen, health care experts are saying that President Trump’s executive order to try to work around the law set by Obamacare will not provide better care and will not lower premiums for Americans. This attempt to circumvent the Affordable Care Act is illegal, will result in more expensive health coverage for many, will open the door for insurance companies to charge more for people with preexisting conditions, and allow these plans not to provide essential benefits such as maternity care or mental health coverage. Expanding the scope of association health plans to allow them to work across multiple states and provide lower level benefits could take employed, young, healthy people out of the private insurance market, which would result in a steep increase in premiums, pricing the Americans most in need of affordable health coverage out of the market. Analyses by the conservative-leaning American Enterprise Institute agrees that this attempted work around by the administration is illegal and will likely not stand up in court.

The protection of the press is enshrined in the Constitution because the Founding Fathers realized that a democracy cannot long survive without a free press. It was so important to them that it was literally the first right they drafted into the Bill of Rights. The President’s bullying--whether threatening the First Amendment because he doesn’t like what he sees on TV, or threatening to cut off aid to Puerto Rico because a crisis makes him look bad—does not reflect Presidential leadership. I try not to get bogged down by his every comment, but these most recent statements cross the line between political demagoguery and authoritarianism. We cannot allow such flagrantly harmful and un-American statements to pass unacknowledged.

In 2015, I supported the passage of the JCPOA agreement because I believed it was the best chance we had to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran. Since then, it has done exactly what is was supposed to, all with intense verification on the part of the P5+1 signatories. The JCPOA is not a perfect agreement, but I still believe this agreement is in the best security interests of my constituents, our nation, for Israel, and the world.   There is universal agreement that the world cannot and will not tolerate a nuclear-armed Iran. The JCPOA remains the best method to accomplish that without the use of military force and the catastrophic violence this would unleash. I believe the President’s action today in decertifying the JCPOA is reckless, tells the world that we don’t honor our commitments, and unnecessarily puts us on the course to armed conflict with Iran.

President Trump has created a constant strain on the healthcare market since before he even took office. Now his actions have graduated from bluster and rhetoric to outright sabotage. More than six million low-income Americans who receive cost-sharing subsidies are now threatened with a loss of their insurance. I also support California’s further action in suing the administration for its efforts not to live up to the promises that the Affordable Care Act granted insurers, states, and the American people.  Read my full statement here:
Last week, I went to the White House to take the message straight to @POTUS: We MUST honor our commitments & uphold the Iran nuclear deal. National Security depends on it.

President Trump boasted yesterday that “Obamacare is finished. It’s dead. It’s gone. You shouldn’t even mention it, it’s gone.” While not true, his comments only show that his actions were never meant to improve or expand on the law, only to sabotage and kill it—threatening the health security of millions of Americans. History, and the American people, will not forget.

I have been deeply moved by all the accounts from everyone who has spoken out to say #MeToo. Your courage is both amazing and inspiring. The silence from so many people who knew and did nothing is deafening. Standing up for what is right should not be hard. We must listen, we must believe, and we must all work together to end the scourge of sexual assault.

The 2017 World Series starts today. Go Dodgers! When I grew up, the Dodgers were my hometown team in Brooklyn. I spent a great deal of time following, watching, and listening to them. This was the team of Snider, Hodges, Campanella, Reese, and Newcombe. And of course, my favorite ball player of all time, Jackie Robinson. Number 42 was living proof that progress was always possible, though never easy. As we come together to root for the Dodgers this week, I will be holding on to that lesson. We need it now more than ever.

I was proud to introduce a bill this week requiring U.S. Interior Secretary Zinke to continue submitting unused oil and gas drilling permit data to Congress each year and to limit future industry hoarding of permits on public land. The oil industry is swamping the system with applications for permits they know they will never use. Earlier this month the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) decided to remove oil and gas permit data from their website because it runs contrary to the narrative of a permit backlog. Public lands belong to all Americans, and the Department of the Interior is entrusted with the responsibility to manage them properly. This bill will increase transparency and encourage the BLM to re-focus their efforts on activities that will actually benefit Americans.

Yesterday, the Department of the Interior’s Bureau of Land Management officially rescinded its Obama-era instructions to consider climate change and weigh the potential for increasing greenhouse gas emissions before approving energy projects. This is yet another in a long line of actions putting the interests of the oil industry ahead of the American people.  This is why the legislation I introduced yesterday along with my colleagues Carlos Curbelo (R-FL), Ted Deutch (D-FL), Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-FL), and Niki Tsongas (D-MA) is so critical. Our bill, the Transparency in Energy Production Act of 2017, would direct the Department of the Interior to develop an online database that collects and centralizes the production and emissions data from fossil fuel development on public lands. The American people deserve transparency from their elected officials and have the absolute right to know how their government is allowing the environment to be impacted.

The President's reported decision to downsize these national monuments is a slap in the face to every American who treasures our public lands, as well as a complete abrogation of our promises and obligations to the Native Americans who have sacred historic and cultural ties to these lands.  The Antiquities Act does not allow a president to rescind or shrink earlier presidential monument designations. This illegal attempt to undo and subvert the preservation of these vital natural and cultural areas is nothing more than a thinly veiled attack on not only Native American heritage and our cherished public lands, but also on the Antiquities Act itself, one of the cornerstones of American conservation law. It puts every national monument in the U.S. at the risk of being political pawns in the pursuit of corporate gain.   These moves are yet another in the Administration's growing list of gifts and handouts to the mining and oil industries, all at the expense of the true owners of these national treasures, the American public and our future generations.

The Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission (CRC) case soon to be argued in front of the U.S. Supreme Court is not about a cake. It is about whether our nation will anoint discrimination against LGBT Americans with the protection of the law.   I have proudly joined in an amicus brief supporting the Colorado CRC in order to stand up for the rights that every American is guaranteed under the Constitution: equal protection under the law.  It is what the labor unions fought for. What the Suffragettes marched in the streets for. It is the idea that the Civil Rights Movement was founded on. And on and on. Movement after movement. The Chicano Movement. The Native American Movement. Disabled Americans. And, of course, the long fight for the equality of LGBT Americans.  These movements each pushed us forward as a nation. They continue to move us forward.   But we cannot for one second take for granted that success in the past guarantees these hard-won rights as immutable.  There are those that will try--that are trying--to take them away. To move us backward instead of forward.  This case is about drawing a line in the sand and saying we will not let you move us backward.  It is--at its core--about who we are and who we will be as Americans.   We have struggled as a nation to move forward step by step and I for one will not stand idly by and allow those that believe in discrimination and division to move us backward and make us less of a nation and a people.  I am proud to sign this brief. I am also proud to stand on the shoulders of so many Americans before me and continue the fight for equality.

There is no denying that our tax code needs to be reformed. Since I've been in Congress I have worked on numerous bills to reform the tax code that would benefit middle-class and lower-income Americans. The new GOP tax plan, however, does not pass my test. This bill is not reform and negatively impacts California taxpayers. Even worse, it is estimated that over ten years this “so-called” tax reform will increase the national debt by more than $1.5 trillion. We pay taxes to promote the general welfare of all Americans. This bill has little to do with this and, in its present form, I do not support it.

The tragedy in Texas breaks my heart and it has left me numb. It has also left me angry. Angry at the silence and refusal by many of our leaders to even talk about the problem. How can we ever hope to understand what would cause such horror without being willing to talk reasonably and honestly about all of the causes? No rational person can sit back and think to themselves that we do not face a growing problem. We have a stark choice as a nation: We can stay silent and grow to accept this all too frequent tragedy, or we can move forward and turn this recurrent grief into concrete action. I, for one, am ready to move forward. I do not know all aspects of the solution, but I know that it does not begin with silence.

The ASTRO Act, which could open huge areas to offshore oil drilling, is unnecessary and wrongheaded. There is a huge environmental risk, all while worsening impacts of climate change. Watch a livestream this afternoon of the House Natural Resources subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resource hearing including my statement:

Let me try to break down what exactly the GOP tax plan could do. It’s not pretty. First, it explodes the deficit by $1.5 trillion. The House GOP leaders argues that growth will create enough revenue to make up for the deficits, but this has never occurred and the very idea has been widely debunked by economists. Second, it would dramatically slash taxes for corporations and the wealthiest Americans in the name of this same “trickle-down” growth. We’ve tried this path before, and the middle class gets peanuts. One only needs to look to the economic disaster in Kansas to see the results of “trickle-down” growth. Third, after a decade, it would raise taxes on a significant number of middle-class households. The New York Times warned that families with 3 or more children could see an immediate increase of $2,000, on average. And it hits the middle classes in other ways, such as ending student loan and medical expense deductions. It also ends state and local tax deductions, which will have a terrible impact on California households. The bill is bad for America. If the Congressional GOP wants to discuss common sense changes to the tax code, I am more than willing to sit down and talk. But this is a smash and grab heist on the budget and the middle class, not “reform.” As it is written, I will oppose it every step of the way.

I was proud to meet today with the U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia William Heidt. As co-chair of the Congressional Cambodia Caucus, it was important for me to hear an “on-the-ground” description from the Ambassador of what is going on in Cambodia. It is not a pretty picture. Ambassador Heidt confirmed to us that the Cambodian government of Prime Minister Hun Sen continues to crack down on his political opponents, non-governmental organizations, the media, and any and all political dissidents, despite the growing public opposition to his more than 30-year rule. It will take the concerted voices of the entire international community to pressure the Hun Sen regime to abide by its obligations to hold free and fair elections in Cambodia next year. We need to continue this pressure. (On my right, Rep. Niki Tsongas; on my left, Ambassador Heidt, Rep. Steve Chabot, and Rep. Ted Yoho.)

Paul Ryan began his tenure as Speaker with a promise to run an inclusive, deliberative House, yet he refuses to bring bills to the floor in regular order and continues to block amendments to bills at historic rates. The result is that good legislative ideas from both parties are blocked. Worse policy, worse results.

I wanted to give everyone a small glimpse into how difficult it is to fight for the environment in today's House. Earlier today during a meeting of the House Natural Resource Committee (HNRC), I proposed an amendment to a funding bill that would have required that the Department of Interior collect and publish information about any climate-damaging pollutants generated by energy development on public lands. By any measure, this is as commonsense as you can get. In addition, the amendment is not regulatory--it simply seeks to collect and disseminate information to the public. I'm proud to say it is based on a bipartisan piece of legislation, with several Republican members of the Climate Solutions Caucus signed on. While every Democrat on the HNRC voted in support, not a single Republican voted in favor—of this non-regulatory legislation other Republicans support, and as a consequence, the amendment failed. I will continue to promote policies that protect our environment, but there are times when the journey towards a better planet is very frustrating. Listen to me introduce the amendment in this clip.
