Veterans Day is our chance to thank those who have served in uniform. It is also our chance to remember and reaffirm our commitment to our brave military service members who have returned home. They have put their lives on the line to assure the safety of our nation, and we must make sure that we deliver on the support we have promised them. They swore an oath to defend our nation and in return deserve our respect and support when they return home.

Climate change is the most critical environmental issue facing our planet. I wanted to highlight this excellent piece from the New York Times which documents in detail the rising costs of climate change and how our inaction and failure to prepare is exacerbating the problem. Our government’s ability to protect lives and property is being hamstrung by a head-in-the-sand denial of basic science.

Brett Talley has been a lawyer for three years and never tried a case. The President nominated the 36-year-old former conservative blogger for a lifetime judgeship on a US District Court and a Senate committee approved him despite the American Bar Association rating him as 'not qualified' – something they have only done to a presidential nominee a handful of times. Talley is now set to get a vote in front of the full Senate. If the Senate GOP is serious about oversight and accountability, now is the time to stand up and vote down this unqualified nominee.

I am deeply disappointed by President Trump’s repeated embrace of serious human rights abusers throughout his trip to Asia, from Cambodia’s Hun Sen to the Philippines’ Duterte. Hun Sen has banished his political opponents and stripped his people of basic human freedoms such as the right of assembly, freedom of the press, and the right to dissent. He is in all but name an autocrat whose regime refuses to relent power after more than 30-years. Duterte has openly called for and celebrated the vigilante killing of civilians outside the due process of law. These are strongmen that the President embraces without a mention of human rights. We CANNOT throw away our moral leadership so flippantly.

According to numbers from the IRS, just one terrible aspect of the GOP tax plan is that it would strip student loan interest deductions from over 1 million Californians, including 21,000 in my district. This is not tax reform for the middle class. It hurts the middle class and discourages education. Shameful and harmful. We can do better.

California is once again leading the way. Our state is on track to get half its energy from renewable sources by 2020 -- 10 years ahead of schedule. California should be a role model for other states when it comes to renewable energy. If we can do it, every state can. Our future depends on it.

The GOP tax bill is already a travesty. The Senate GOP threatens to make it even worse by adding yet another attack on Obamacare which would spike premiums and further attack the middle class, all to finance tax cuts for Donald Trump and his billionaire friends. The Senate version could reduce the number of Americans with healthcare by 13 million. Following suit, the House GOP version of the tax bill already attacks healthcare. Nine million Americans could be affected. The CBO says that the House tax bill could cut $25 billion from Medicare immediately. Both versions are unacceptable and outrageous. And, as always, we should remember that the premise of the bill is false. Tax cuts for the top 1% don’t create growth or jobs. They create inequality and ever-increasing deficits. I was proud to speak today at a rally on Capitol Hill taking on this bill, which for the sake of middle-class Americans, must not pass.

I am deeply disappointed at the passage of the House GOP’s tax bill. This is not over and there remains a long road ahead before it could ever become law. I will continue to push back at this terrible legislation every chance I get. It is bad for California and bad for our nation’s middle class, and the majority of Americans know it.

The Cambodian Supreme Court, controlled by Prime Minister Hun Sen, yesterday ruled that the major political opposition party in the nation must dissolve and all sitting government members of the party are expelled from their offices. This is a dark day for the fledgling democracy of Cambodia. Hun Sen, in banning his main political opposition party, has effectively turned Cambodia into his own personal autocracy: his main political opposition is banned, many of its members have fled, some have been arrested, the independent press outlets have been shuttered, and civic organizations have been silenced. For the time being, this is the end of democracy in Cambodia. Read my full statement here:

Yesterday, a 210,000 gallon spill occurred in South Dakota on a portion of the Keystone pipeline system that runs nearly 3,000 miles from Canada to Nebraska and Illinois. This is exactly what people are worried about when they raise concerns about oil pipeline infrastructure. The spill is one of several leaks that have hit the pipeline network in recent years. This pipeline is owned by the same company that is attempting to build the Keystone XL pipeline. Next week, Nebraska authorities will decide whether the Keystone XL will receive a key state permit to begin construction. This XL sister to the existing Keystone pipeline will run nearly 1,200 miles from Canada to the southern edge of Nebraska.

I am proud to join 12 of my House colleagues to cosponsor Congresswoman Bonamici’s bill, the Ruthie and Connie LGBT Elder Americans Act. The bill would improve the Older Americans Act (OAA) to better serve senior LGBT Americans and increase access to services and support programs. The legislation would establish a National Resource Center on LGBT Aging with the mission of improving the quality of services and supports offered to LGBT seniors. The legislation would also address the lack of accurate data about LGBT seniors by requiring the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services’ Assistant Secretary of Aging to collect data on LGBT older adults to determine the needs of the population.  The legislation is named after long-time LGBT equality advocates Ruthie Berman and Connie Kurtz.

Today, on the Transgender Day of Remembrance, we take a pause to remember the many transgender lives cut short due to violence caused by hatred, discrimination and often fearful ignorance--simply because of who they are. This has been the deadliest year in the United States for transgender people--that we know of--with 25 transgender women killed across the nation. The brutality must end. We must do our best to create a world without hatred and bigotry and work toward a world of acceptance, love, and support.

I remain committed to and will continue to fight for net neutrality. Today’s draft released by FCC Chairman Pai would dismantle federal net neutrality protections for consumers. This action was, sadly, predictable, but nonetheless extremely disappointing. Congress must act to prevent this misguided policy from taking effect, and put in place strong protections for consumers and entrepreneurs. Dismantling these protections will leave broadband subscribers with little protection and further stack the deck in favor of large broadband companies. An open internet is in the best interest of our nation and all Americans.

Sexual harassment is abhorrent. No one can be allowed to commit these acts with impunity. The growing number of accusations across all walks of life, including Congress, have shone a light on a darkness that has been hiding in plain sight for far too long. My heart goes out to those who have been forced to carry the burden of trauma in silence, often for years: our society owes you justice and reform. I stand with the victims and demand accountability.

If President Trump does in fact nominate Thomas Brunell as the head operational officer of the U.S. Census Bureau, the President would be breaking with the long tradition of choosing a nonpolitical government official to effectively lead that department. Brunell has neither government or statistical science experience. In fact, the nominee has even written a book entitled “Redistricting and Representation: Why Competitive Elections Are Bad for America.”   One of the most important functions of the Census Bureau is the decennial census conducted every ten years, with the next being set for 2020. This census will determine not only which states lose and gain electoral votes and seats in the House of Representatives, but using the information gathered, states will redraw their Congressional districts. What’s more, Census data underpins nearly every government program. It is critical for the function of our republic that the census be both scientific, objective, and nonpartisan. The fairness of elected institutions and the accuracy of government data depend on it. Putting it in partisan hands would be unacceptable.

The Trump Administration has given 60,000 Haitian refugees—who fled to the US after the devastating 2010 Haitian earthquake—just 18 months to leave the US. The Administration’s decision to end the Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for the Haitian refugees is outrageous and deeply cruel. Haiti has struggled with subsequent disasters and public health emergencies as it tries to rebuild, and so many of those displaced have no home to return to. The TPS program has existed since 1990 and previous administrations have all extended the status on numerous occasions, including for displaced people from Haiti. I have pushed this Administration to extend the status for these people, and I believe Congress must take concrete action to reverse this decision.

Just a reminder that Covered California health insurance open enrollment is going on right now and runs through Jan. 31, 2018. You can get started exploring your options at Covered California’s website.

The ports of Long Beach and Los Angeles, and other ports that have used our ports as role models, have made great strides in modernizing their cargo-hauling truck fleets. Diesel emissions in the ports are down significantly due to these efforts. However, in a major step backward, the Trump Administration has moved to exempt certain refurbished trucks from meeting EPA air emissions guidelines. The trucks in question—manufactured almost exclusively by a single Tennessee company--cost 25 percent less than new trucks but pollute up to 40 times more than a new truck. More than 10,000 of these trucks are made each year. With no regulation, the exempt trucks—which make up less than 5 percent of the national truck fleet—could account for 33 percent of all truck emissions by 2025. This is appalling and is just another in this administration’s continuing attacks on our environmental safety.

Around the turn of the 20th Century, a man named George Parker made a name for himself with his surprisingly successful con of selling the Brooklyn Bridge over and over again. He did it by doing what most con artists do—telling people what they want to hear. The Senate GOP is trying to do the same thing with their tax bill that they hope to vote on this week. They say it is just tax relief for the middle class. If you believe that, then you might also inquire if they have a bridge to sell.   The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has released their score of the Senate tax bill, and it is not good for Americans in the lowest income brackets. The CBO found that the tax bill would negatively impact individuals who make less than $30,000 per year by 2019, while most of those making under $75,000 would be negatively affected by 2027. The CBO report also found that poor Americans would lose billions of dollars worth of federal benefits under the Senate GOP tax bill. Needless to say, the report found that those in the top income brackets will be receiving the majority of the tax relief. The GOP are selling a bill of goods to the American people. George Parker would be proud.

Today President Trump retweeted multiple Islamophobic propaganda videos originally posted by the leader of the UK far-right extremist group, Britain First. So just to be clear, our President of the US spent his morning promoting an ultra-nationalist political hate group whose leaders—including the one who originally posted the videos--have been previously arrested and convicted in the UK for hate crimes. These videos, beyond being unverified (and one already proving to be untrue), are abhorrent and it is disturbing and shameful that our President would try to normalize this kind of hate. He must remove these tweets and apologize immediately.

In a world that is becoming more dangerous and needs us to marshal all our forces of diplomacy and statecraft, it makes no sense to deliberately decimate our own diplomatic corps. The senseless weakening of the State Department may prove to be one of the most lasting and harmful legacies of this Administration and its marginalization of diplomacy. I will fight against the potentially devastating 31 percent cuts proposed for the State Department budget. I will also continue to demand the U.S. prioritize human rights, diplomacy, and statesmanship, which remain the bedrock of American strength and leadership throughout the world. It is regrettable that the President and Secretary Tillerson do not appear to recognize this.

Politico has released the results of a survey of Congressional offices they conducted which details that sexual harassment policies vary widely across the individual Congressional offices that responded. I wanted to let you know where I stand on this issue and detail my specific office policies. I have not—and never will—allow harassment or discrimination of any kind in my office. This includes any form of sexual harassment. Since I joined Congress in 2013, my official office employee handbook has clearly stated this. As a step in strengthening our training, in January of this year, I mandated that all my staff take annual sexual harassment training. Every member of my staff, including myself and every intern, have completed this training. But, this is only one small step. Deeper reforms are needed to protect all congressional employees. It is a serious responsibility to ensure a safe and healthy workplace for all my employees: I owe that not only to my staff, but also to my constituents.

Yesterday marked exactly two months since Congressional funding authorization for the Children’s Healthcare Insurance Program (CHIP) expired. While the House GOP included CHIP funding in funding legislation several months ago, they rolled in severe cuts to numerous social programs that made the legislation nearly impossible to pass in the Senate, where the funding has yet to be brought to the Senate floor. Low-income children, pregnant women, and families across the nation depend on CHIP for healthcare, including 2 million children in California. California CHIP funds from the federal government—more than $2.5 billion a year--could run out as early as late December. This move could cost California hundreds of millions to maintain coverage. Another month must not go by before Congress reauthorizes this critical program.

Thrilled to see that the City of Westminster will be receiving a grant to commemorate the landmark Mendez v. Westminster School District case—a historic case which led to the full desegregation of California schools. The 1947 Supreme Court case arose because the Mendez children were refused school enrollment except in a segregated city-run “Mexican School”. The Supreme Court ruling in the case led almost immediately to California Governor Earl Warren (and future Chief Justice of the United States who would preside over the Brown v. Board of Education case) signing legislation which repealed all remaining segregationist provisions in California statutes.

I applaud California’s action to sue Ashford “University”. Many of these for-profit universities act as predators on young eager minds seeking an education. Since the current Administration has taken steps to undermine Obama-era protections against such actions by these for-profit universities, it will be up to states and Congress to act as safeguards.

The President today illegally ordered the boundaries of the Bears Ears and the Grand Staircase Escalante national monuments dramatically reduced.  The Antiquities Act—which allows presidents to create national monuments—expressly does not allow a president to rescind or shrink earlier presidential monument designations. This unlawful attempt to undo and subvert the preservation of these vital natural and cultural areas is nothing more than a thinly veiled attack on not only Native American heritage and our cherished public lands, but also on the Antiquities Act itself, one of the cornerstones of American conservation law. It is also a complete capitulation of our public lands to mining and petroleum corporations. These actions put every national monument in the U.S. at the risk of being political pawns in the pursuit of corporate gain.

Today, I was proud to speak at a rally on the steps of the U.S. Supreme Court, where inside the Justices were hearing oral arguments in the Masterpiece Cake case. This is the case of a Colorado baker who refused—on the grounds of his religious beliefs—to bake a cake for a same-sex couple. The case could have a significant impact on the civil rights of millions upon millions of Americans, well beyond the LGBT community. Please take a moment and read my full comments to the rally:

There is no question that the entire process of how workplace harassment is handled on Capitol Hill must be overhauled from top to bottom. The current system has led to a situation where there is almost zero accountability and puts the onus on victims. This is why I am a vocal supporter and proud cosponsor of the bipartisan ME TOO Congress Act legislation introduced by Rep. Jackie Speier of California. This legislation would eliminate onerous filing time limits; create a new, optional in-house victims' counsel position to provide legal advice and representation for complainants; eliminate requirements on victims signing non-disclosure agreements; create an online system to initiate complaints; require Congress Members to pay out of pocket for any settled claim where they are identified as the harasser; require public disclosure of the employing office when a claim is settled and to disclose the settlement amount; require an anonymous "climate survey" of congressional employees every two years; and extend all protections to interns, fellows and pages. Every employee on Capitol Hill deserves these protections and every American needs to know that their government treats its employees properly.

Less than two months after two of the deadliest shootings in modern American history, the House GOP today passed the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act--an egregious and extreme bill that is nothing more than a giveaway to the NRA. It would force states to honor concealed carry permits from any other state. This will trigger a catastrophic race to the bottom in gun regulation and make the weakest and most dangerous state concealed carry laws the law of the land in all 50 states. The GOP is responding to mass shootings by forcing Californians to accept the same safety standards as those state with the weakest regulations. This is not only irresponsible policy, and a flagrant attack on the ability of communities to protect their own citizens, but it makes our nation less safe.

I believe in a two-state solution in the Middle East and believe that the U.S. should be an honest broker in coming up with a durable lasting peace. I also believe that today--more than ever--a unilateral move by the U.S. in relocating its embassy prior to meaningful peace talks, will be a huge setback to successful peace efforts to create that two-state solution.   I support the 1995 law passed by Congress requiring the U.S. to move its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. I also understand and appreciate why since 1995 Presidents Clinton, Bush, and Obama declined to move the embassy, citing national security interests. They knew that it was not the right time--just as today is not the right time.   This is why I disagree with President Trump's decision to begin the process of moving the U.S. Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

Today, I was proud to introduce a bipartisan House Resolution honoring the 69th Anniversary of Human Rights Day on Dec. 10 and the ratification on Dec. 10, 1948, by the United Nations of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR).  The promotion of respect for human rights as embodied in the UDHR is a key component of the leadership role the United States plays around the world. The Congress, and the world, must recognize that those who are denied basic human rights, such as the freedoms of speech, religion, and political expression, are also denied basic human respect and dignity. It diminishes our shared humanity when people are denied these basic and universal rights. The world would be a safer place if human rights were universally protected.

For proponents of drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, the results of an oil and gas lease sale in the neighboring National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska (NPR-A) must be quite disappointing.  On Wednesday, the Trump Administration released bids for oil and gas leases in the (NPR-A). Unfortunately, the 10-million-acre auction in the NPR-A resulted in just 7 bids out of the 900 leases for auction. The whole auction only raised $1.2 million. At the same time, the GOP is proposing to open up 1.5 million acres of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas development in their tax bill. In fact, they believe based on Congressional Budget Office estimates that the ANWR lease would bring in $2.2 billion and help offset some of the corporate giveaways in their tax bill. If it suffers from the same fate as the NPR-A auction, the ANWR auction would only net $180,000—far short of the $2.2 billion the GOP counted on to help make their tax bill add up. Yesterday, I joined with Reps. Raul Grijalva and Jared Huffman in calling on the CBO to reassess the ANWR cost estimate that features so prominently in the GOP tax bill. This is yet another sign of the serious flaws in the GOP tax bill. Read the letter by clicking on the link below.

Fifty years ago today, the Queen Mary arrived in Long Beach Harbor to the cheers, horns, and whistles of thousands of welcomers in hundreds of boats. She almost instantly became, and remains, an icon of the city. Here is hoping that the currently ongoing major renovation and upgrade project will give her another fifty years as one of the great symbols of Long Beach.

I was truly saddened to hear of the passing of the Most. Rev. Dominic Luong, the first native-born Vietnamese Roman Catholic bishop in the United States. His contribution to our community in Orange County—and his incredible work with immigrant and refugee communities nationwide--will live on.

The deception continues. The political staff of the Treasury Dept. has now issued a one-page analysis of the GOP tax plan. It conflicts with all independent analyses of the plan from expert economists. The Treasury analysis rests on the assumption that the GOP tax bill will increase the annual Gross Domestic Product a full percentage point more than the GDP projections by the Congressional Budget Office for the next decade. Other analyses are not nearly this optimistic.The Joint Committee on Taxation, Congress' nonpartisan scorekeeper, estimated it would add less than one-tenth of one percent to yearly GDP growth.   Other analyses point out that the GOP plan will also significantly increase the deficit. The Tax Policy Center said the Senate version would cost $1.5 trillion over 10 years, and the Penn-Wharton Budget Model predicts anywhere from $1.5 trillion to $1.8 trillion added to the debt. This is a bill of goods being sold to the American public—a giveaway to the wealthy being foisted on the backs of working Americans today and their children in the future.

The 47th Congressional District is home to one of the largest Cambodian communities outside of Cambodia and many of my constituents still hold deep ties to Cambodia, both familial and historic. I was honored to be able to join Radio Free Asia’s premier Khmer news program yesterday to discuss the deteriorating political situation inside Cambodia. I was also honored to be told that I was the first Congress Member to appear on the program, which is transmitted to viewers in Cambodia via the internet. Prime Minister Hun Sen’s regime continues to crack down on all political opposition and violate the human and democratic rights promised to the Cambodia people under their constitution. We must join with the international community to bring all the diplomatic and political pressure to bear to guarantee the rights of all Cambodians.

As the decision approaches on net neutrality, a new University of Maryland poll shows that 83 percent of voters oppose the FCC’s plan to repeal net neutrality rules. I agree with the majority of Americans the we should keep the internet fair and accessible, and I’ve urged Chairman Pai to delay this vote. When the FCC votes tomorrow, they should hear the voice of the people. No matter the decision from the FCC, I will continue to fight for the needs of internet users over the profits of internet providers.

Today, US Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein reaffirmed what we already knew: there is no cause for Trump to shut down Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s inquiry. I am proud to support the bipartisan Special Counsel Integrity Act, which was introduced in August, and would block any move to improperly end the investigation prematurely. It is critical, whatever the results, that the Special Counsel be given the time to complete his investigations without interference or obstruction.

In yet another example of this administration’s kowtowing to corporate special interests and its complete disregard for the will of the people, the Trump Federal Communications Commission voted to end net neutrality. Like the overwhelming majority of Americans, I was profoundly disappointed by the partisan decision that even the majority of the internet industry opposed. While this will eventually be decided in court, the FCC decision has put net neutrality, and the fair and open internet, on life-support.

A good article by Andrew Edwards at the LB Press-Telegram explaining how the expiration of the Children Health Insurance Program (CHIP) could harm Long Beach and its residents. The GOP has spent nearly two months creating a bait and switch tax bill for corporate America that adds over a trillion to the debt, but then drag their feet to provide healthcare for millions of children. Their priorities are out of kilter with the American public. CHIP funding must be passed now.

The House GOP tax bill passed today embodies everything Americans dislike about Congress. It was drafted behind closed doors, while the drafters cast aside expert analysis and relied instead on special interests and faulty, disproven assumptions. The plan slashes tax rates for multinational corporations and the super-wealthy, but leaves hardworking Americans in the 47th District to pay the bill. It penalizes taxpayers in California and other blue states for investing in our schools, roads, and public services. And it cruelly hits children, seniors, and low-income Americans by putting at risk Medicare, Medicaid, SNAP, and Social Security. I could not (and proudly did not) vote for this disastrous piece of legislation. I will not forget the way this was foisted on the American people, and I believe the American people will not forget either.

Today, the House voted again on the GOP tax bill, due to procedural errors the drafters created in their back-door chaotic rush to push their horrible legislation through Congress. I voted against this bill again, just as I would vote against any legislation that is so harmful, cruel and insensitive to the American working class. Over the past weeks, this bill has been referred to as everything from a scam to a bait-and-switch scheme. I believe that the American people—who already overwhelmingly disapprove of it—will come to see it as nothing more than an outright heist of the American working class by the GOP in their role as water bearers for the monied interests in this country.

I was proud this week to join 120 colleagues in signing a letter to FBI Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein calling on him protect the integrity and independence of Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation. The Special Counsel and his team must be allowed to complete their investigation. President Trump must know any attempt to end this investigation will unleash a political crisis he will not be able to contain. Read the entire letter on my website by clicking below.

The House GOP (and the White House) is celebrating adding as much as $2 trillion dollars to the deficit while slashing taxes for the wealthiest and raising taxes on millions of California working class families. Now they’re leaving town without action on any of the following crucial priorities:   • They failed to renew long-term funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program, putting millions of low-income children in immediate risk. • Stabilizing Obamacare markets. Congress must offset the premium increases caused by their irresponsible repeal of the individual mandate. • The GOP failed to provide legal protections to DREAMers, who remain threatened with deportation, even though this is the only country they have ever known. • They failed to stand up to the President to guarantee the independence of Special Counsel Mueller's Investigation.

Under the Trump Administration EPA and Interior Dept., 2017 has been a disastrous year for the environment and for the conservation and protection of our public lands.   Most recently, the Administration has dropped climate change as an official US national security threat. Combined with his decision earlier this year to withdraw from the universally-adopted Paris Accord and the Administration's shift toward aggressive fossil fuel development--even in our most precious protected public lands--the US now finds itself pitted against not only the scientific certainty of overwhelming human involvement in climate change, but against the rest of the world's efforts to reverse the process.    As a member of the House Natural Resources Committee I will continue to fight to keep our environmental protections in place and to prevent our public lands from being turned over to corporate special interests.

It's been a challenging year for unions and workers under the Trump Administration's National Labor Relations Board (NLRB). Originally created under FDR, the NLRB was charged with enforcing US labor law related to collective bargaining and unfair labor practices. Under President Trump's control, the NLRB has become a cudgel against unions instead of an agency to protect workers. It has already reversed several major NLRB positions on organizing created during the Obama era. These Trump-era rulings make it clear that despite his promises to be a "friend" of unions during the campaign, the President typically supports corporate employers at the expense of American workers.
